snippet: The word the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has used more than any other is free, but he now finds himself in a genteel prison, without limit of sentence.
abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange finds himself facing a long stay in Ecuador's embassy in London, after the British government vows to arrest him the moment he steps out of the building, despite Ecuador's decision to grant him asylum.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by William Neuman from Caracas, Venezuela; Maggy Ayala from Quito, Ecuador; Ravi Somaiya and Alan Cowell from London; and Christina Anderson from Stockholm.

lead_paragraph: The word the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has used more than any other is free, but he now finds himself in a genteel prison, without limit of sentence.

headline.seo: Assange Faces Long Stay in Ecuador’s Embassy in London
headline.main: Assange Faces Long Stay in Ecuador’s London Embassy
headline.print_headline: Assange Faces Long Stay In Ecuador’s Embassy
